description.narrative: IDH has focused the work of the landscape program on the concept of PPI: Production-Protection-Inclusion. IDH is implementing this concept through the development of PPI compacts in 11 landscapes in seven countries. These are agreements between public, private and civil society parties to enhance sustainable productive land and secure livelihoods in exchange for natural resource conservation. IDH convenes coalitions that develop these compacts. The compacts are based on participatory land-use planning, whereby land for production (increasing productivity), livelihoods (income diversification, resilience, access to markets) and protection (forest, water, soil) is clearly identified, and their related uses are agreed on by the landscape stakeholders and recognized by local and national governments. The compacts also include goals for each of the PPI components, a time-bound plan of action, clear definition of roles and responsibilities, and a budget for implementation. The compacts are the basis for the PPI Fund and other investors to invest in the landscapes, as well as the basis for regional sourcing by supply chain companies. This will result in coalitions that are self-sustaining, are linked to markets, and prove the business case for landscape-level interventions and investments.

title.narrative: Result Area 1 - Change in business practice
Private sector (sustainability) investments in the program

description.narrative: The actual realized eligible private sector investments per program (in €)

comment.narrative: Budgeted 2020 contributions by private sector (excl. SNV and Rhino Ark) projects: integrated livestock project, biogas for tea outgrowers, livestock upscaling, rehabilitation and regeneration, aerial surveillance (assumed 20880/2 years) and Bongo surveillance program

description.narrative: Qualitative description about the embeddedness of sustainability at corporate level of companies/industry organizations/business platforms (this description should provide information on what have changed over the last reporting period in terms of their approach towards sustainability issues, including responsible sourcing and Protection Producdtion Inclusion criteria in case of the landscapes programs)

comment.narrative: The results from previous years have been updated in this report. In total, 6 companies in the landscape signed the ISLA Kenya Action Plan (April 2017) and are playing a role in the Stawisha-Mau Charitable Trust, either as Board members or in a Technical Working Group: KTDA, Unilever Tea Kenya, James Finlay Kenya, KENGEN, the Timber Manufacturers Association, and Safaricom. KTDA, Unilever, Finlays, and Safaricom have been co-investing in several field-level projects since 2016. The tea companies became familiar with a landscape approach through the ISLA program and report on this in their annual sustainability reports. Some of them started other landscape initiatives in other countries, following the example set by ISLA Kenya and others.
Define the roles and responsibilities of the companies within the coalition (and other partners) in the overall landscape management plan and get the plan signed

title.narrative: Business cases developed within the IDH program to show the potential of sustainable practices

description.narrative: The number and description of business cases that have been developed within the IDH program to demonstrate to the private sector the potential of sustainable practices adopted and implemented by other organizations

comment.narrative: Livestock intensification is the key focus of business case development. IDH is working with SNV to develop a business case for farmers to invest in an intensified dairy production system as opposed to forest grazing. This is based on farm investments, improved practices, improved milk yield, sales and income. In 2017, the baseline data required for this business case was collected. IDH is co-funding the livestock pilot and providing the monitoring and evaluation framework for the business case. A geothermal energy feasibility study was performed together with Unilever Tea Kenya and James Finlays Kenya. The study proved that geothermal energy alone would not be feasible, and further research for a sound financial business case is required. Based on a revised definition, the combined buffer in combination with a trust was not pursued as a business case. The focus going forward to 2020 remains on the livestock business case due to its potential impact on improving livelihoods and reducing pressure on the forest.
Start to build business case for livestock intensification for forest protection

The livestock intensification pilot trained 200 dairy smallholders and demonstrated a 40% daily yield increase per cow and a 40% milk price increase from 2017 to 2018. Efforts to improve the farmers’ access to milk markets has resulted in, for example, one cooperative (Olenguruone) collecting 1,000 liters/day from farmers in the pilot area by the end of 2018, up from zero before that.
Bioslurry

title.narrative: Representation and commitment of key-stakeholders in multi-stakeholder processes or coalitions

description.narrative: The indicator score is provided by a self-assessment performed by all stakeholders that are involved in the multi-stakeholder processes associated with the program or landscape. On an annual basis, all stakeholders that are active in the processes receive a request to complete a brief electronic questionnaire. The assessment is done through a set of statements focusing on the satisfaction, representation and commitment of the multi-stakeholder processes and coalitions as part of the IDH programs.

comment.narrative: *Paused in 2019

title.narrative: Satisfaction about the effectiveness of multi-stakeholder processes or coalitions associated with the program

description.narrative: The perceived satisfaction by the participating stakeholders (i.e. private sector, government, NGOs) of the multi-stakeholder process or coalitions in which they participate.

comment.narrative: *Paused in 2019

title.narrative: Changes at policy and regulatory level contributing to increased sustainability of commodity production and improved management of natural resources

description.narrative: Qualitative description explaining the background and progress of the changes in policies, regulations, and/or enforcement of these as a result of IDH interventions. This includes Sector policies; economic and fiscal policies (e.g. tax policies rewarding sustainable business practices); social or environmental policies (e.g. on agrochemical management, forest protection, water management, gender issues).

comment.narrative: With support from the Netherlands Embassy in Kenya, IDH started a dialogue on the Mau Forest between ISLA partners and the national government through the Ministry of Environment. Partners presented a memorandum to the Minister requesting national government recognition, political and budgetary support. IDH was instrumental in securing the meeting through the Embassy, getting partners together, aligning on the message delivered, and ongoing follow-up with the Ministry. KFS and KWS officers facilitated improving capacity to monitor and address illegal activities through joint surveillance flights, additional camping equipment, and law enforcement training.
Program target achieved in 2017.

description.narrative: The identification and stage of development of plans that are developed by a coalition of stakeholders in the landscape in which IDH operates, including but not limited to: Green growth plans; Land-use plans; Landscape protection plans; Action plans of PPI compacts or landscape coalitions

comment.narrative: An integrated management plan is developed for South West Mau and Transmara Forest blocks

The Stawisha Mau Charitable Trust was registered in 2017. In 2018, it is expected to adopt the ISLA action plan. In 2018, IDH will work with partners, especially Kenya Forest Service, towards an integrated management plan for the South West Mau Forest.
Translate the existing action plan into an integrated management plan that is agreed between ISLA partners and Kenya Forest Service
The existing action plan is translated into an integrated management plan that is agreed between ISLA partners and Kenya Forest Service.

title.narrative: Number of hectares where protection and restoration interventions are implemented

description.narrative: Number of hectares, type of ecosystem protected (e.g. forest/peatland/grassland), quality of the ecosystem protected (e.g. HCV/HCS area); Type of protection and/or restoration activity. It should include as much as possible information on the effectiveness of the protection and restoration measures

comment.narrative: The entire area targeted by the program is 59,000 hectares which is the total remaining dense forest, moderate forest, and open forest in the focal landscape (confirmed in GISbased data in 2018 baseline report), where we are employing our forest protection and restoration activities. Besides direct afforestation measures, the program also implements: aerial surveillance program (leading to increased conviction of illegal loggers and charcoal makers), improved onthe- ground surveillance, and measures to reduce cattle grazing in the forest.
The annual progress and targets refer to direct afforestation efforts.

title.narrative: Number of trainers, auditors and/or government staff trained in the program

description.narrative: Several programs have indicated they will develop curricula or guidance for service delivery or extension of good practices. This indicator looks at whether this is being achieved, and whether the next step is taken, being the training of trainers and auditors to use these deliverables.

comment.narrative: Result 2019 was lower than anticipated because the expected funding from the German International Climate Initiative (IKI) was not granted due to political risks in the landscape; the livestock projects therefore had to be adjusted to a smaller scale than originally foreseen. The construction of the fence did not take place either following political developments. Result 2019 number refers to training of trainers under livestock intensification pilot and community conservation champions in RhinoArk Conservation Projects.
Translate the existing action plan into an integrated management plan agreed between ISLA partners and Kenya Forest Service

title.narrative: # of producers/workers/community members trained on key subjects for sustainable production, environmental and social sustainability issues

description.narrative: The number of producers/workers/community members trained on key subjects for sustainable production, environmental and social sustainability issues to capture the scale and reach of the work on the ground

comment.narrative: Result 2019 was lower than anticipated because the expected funding from the German International Climate Initiative (IKI) was not granted due to political risks in the landscape; the livestock projects therefore had to be adjusted to a smaller scale than originally foreseen. The construction of the fence did not take place either following political developments. Farmers were trained in the following projects: livestock intensification pilot, including training on water harvesting, biogas, kitchen gardering, agroforestry (200); CFA community members – unique numbers trained in the integrated livestock project (430); community members trained on beekeeping (476), and through youth and church group conservation (302) under Rhino Ark Conservation Projects.
Livestock upscaling will reach 1,000 farmers; biogas for tea outgrowers will reach 100 farmers; Adopt-a-Forest project extension will train 55 people

description.narrative: The number, type, and function of infrastructure facilities developed that are instrumental in achieving environmental protection or sustainable commodity production in the landscape

1st part of fence 30 km long, 150 hectares of Adopta- Forest rehabilitation

title.narrative: Number of hectares where sustainable production/farm rehabilitation/sustainable intensification are implemented

description.narrative: This indicator measures the area covered by actions that aim to achieve sustainable agriculture and/or forestry in the landscape / jurisdiction.

comment.narrative: 22 fodder production and paddocking at homesteads
3,100 of which: Household area under sustainable livestock production: 2,000. Sustainable grazing: 200. Forest land under sustainable grazing: 1,000. Tea buffer zone: 100
258 fodder production and paddocking at homesteads
